review.title: Performance Analysis of Clustering Algorithms for Gene Expression Data
review.abstract: Microarray technology is a process that allows thousands of genes simultaneously monitor to various experimental conditions. It is used to identify the co-expressed genes in specific cells or tissues that are actively used to make proteins, This method is used to analysis the gene expression, an important task in bioinformatics research. Cluster analysis of gene expression data has proved to be a useful tool for identifying co-expressed genes, biologically relevant groupings of genes and samples. In this paper we analysed K-Means with Automatic Generations of Merge Factor for ISODATA- AGMFI, to group the microarray data sets on the basic of ISODATA. AGMFI is to generate initial values for merge and Spilt factor, maximum merge times instead of selecting efficient values as in ISODATA. The initial seeds for each cluster were normally chosen either sequentially or randomly. The quality of the final clusters was found to be influenced by these initial seeds. For the real life problems, the suitable number of clusters cannot be predicted. To overcome the above drawback the current research focused on developing the clustering algorithms without giving the initial number of clusters.
histories: 4 pages,4 figures. arXiv admin note: substantial text overlap witharXiv:1112.4261,arXiv:1201.4914,arXiv:1307.3337
review.COMMENTS: 4 pages,4 figures. arXiv admin note: substantial text overlap witharXiv:1112.4261,arXiv:1201.4914,arXiv:1307.3337

metadata.title: Performance Analysis of Clustering Algorithms for Gene Expression Data

sections.text: This method is used to analyze gene expression, an important task in bioinformatics research. Cluster analysis of gene expression data has proven to be a useful tool for identifying co-expressed genes, biologically relevant groupings of genes and samples. In this work, we analyzed K-Means with Automatic Generations of Merge Factor for ISODATA - AGMFI to group the microarray data sets based on ISODATA. AGMFI is to generate initial values for merge and donation factor, to select maximum merge times, rather than efficient values as in ISODATA. Initial seeds for each cluster were usually selected either sequentially or randomly, and the quality of the final cluster was influenced by these initial data. It is not possible to predict the appropriate number of clusters for real life problems.

sections.heading: 1 INTRODUCTION
sections.text: The results of these experiments are usually presented in the form of a data matrix in which rows and columns represent conditions [12]. Each entry in the matrix is a measure of the expression level of a particular gene under a particular condition. Analysis of these data sets shows genes of unknown functions and the discovery of functional relationships between genes [18]. The most popular cluster algorithms in gene expression analysis are hierarchical clustering [11], K-Means clustering [3] and SOM [8].

sections.heading: 2 RELATED WORK
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 2.1 K- Means Clustering
sections.text: The main objective of cluster analysis is the grouping of objects that are similar in a cluster and separate objects that differ from each other by assigning them to different clusters. One of the most popular cluster analysis methods is the K-Means cluster algorithm [3, 9, 12, 17], whereby objects are assigned to a predefined number of clusters specified by the user (let's assume K clusters). The idea is to select random cluster centers, one for each cluster. These centers will preferably be as far away from each other as possible. In this algorithm, mainly euclidean distance is used to find the distance between data points and centerings [6]. Euclidean distance between two multidimensional data points X = (x1, x2, x3,..., xm) and Y = (y1, y2, y3,..., y3,..., yym) is described as follows: (X, quadrate, Y = the sum of the Y-Means method aimed at adding all clusters).

sections.heading: 2. Repeat
sections.text: Assign each point di to the cluster that has the narrowest centroid; calculate the new mean for each cluster; until convergence criteria are met. Although the K-Means algorithm is simple, it has some disadvantages in terms of the quality of final clustering, as it depends heavily on the arbitrary selection of the initial centroid [1].

sections.heading: 2.2 Iterative Self-Organizing Data Analysis Techniques
sections.text: ISODATA algorithms Variation is to allow splitting and merging of the resulting clusters. Typically, a cluster is split if its variance is above a predetermined threshold, and two clusters are merged if the distance between their centroids is below another predetermined threshold [14]. With this variant, it is possible to obtain the optimal partition from any initial partition, provided that the correct thresholds are set. ISODATA's well-known algorithm uses more clustering technique of merging and splitting clusters. If ISODATA specifies the "ellipse" partition as the initial partitioning, it will produce the optimal threshold of three-dimensional ISODATA partitioning, the clusters {A} and {B, C} will merge into a cluster first, since the distance between their clusters is small and then split the clusters.

sections.heading: 2.3 Automatic Generation of Merge Factor for ISODATA (AGMFI) Algorithm
sections.text: Some of the parameters are set by the user as the clusters are merged and partitioned. [10] proposes to automatically initialize the merge factor for ISODATA. AGMFI uses various heuristics to determine when the merge should take place. Algorithm 3: The AGMFI algorithm [10] Input: D = {d1, d2, d3,..., dn} / / Set of n data points. K - Number of desired clusters. m- Minimum number of samples in a cluster; n - Maximum number of iterations.

sections.heading: 3 CLUSTER CENTRE INITIALIZATION ALGORITHM
sections.text: (CCIA) The performance of iterative cluster center initialization algorithms, which converge to numerous local minimums, depends greatly on the initial cluster centers. Generally, the initial cluster centers are randomly selected. In this section, the cluster center initialization algorithm is examined to improve the performance of the K-Means algorithm. Algorithm 4: Find the initial centroids [17] Input: D = {d1, d2,..., dn} / / Set of n data points itemsK / / Number of desired cluster output: A set of K initial centroids. Steps: 1. Set m = 1; 2. Calculate the distance between each data point and other data points in set D; 3. Find the next data point from set D and form a data point Am (1 ≤ m ≤ K) containing these two data points, Delete these two data points from set D; 4. Find the data point in the data point, the next data point to the data point, and add it to the data point at the next step D and D =

sections.heading: 4 EXPERIMENTAL ANALYSIS AND DISCUSSION
sections.text: The following data sets are used to analyze the methods examined in sections 2 and 3.

sections.heading: 4.1 Serum Data
sections.text: This dataset is described and used in [10] and can be downloaded from: http: / / www.sciencemag.org / feature / data / 984559.shl and corresponds to the selection of 517 genes whose expression varies according to serum concentration in human fibroblasts.

sections.heading: 4.2 Yeast data
sections.text: This dataset contains 2884 genes and 17 conditions. To avoid distortion or distortion due to missing values in the data matrix, we remove all genes that had a missing value. This step results in a matrix of size 2882 * 17. The suggested matrix contains integers ranging from 1 to 500.

sections.heading: 4.3 Simulated Data
sections.text: It can be downloaded from http: / / www.igbmc.ustrasbg.fr / projets / fcm / y3c.txt The set contains 300 genes [3]. Above the microarray data set, all values in each gene are normalized: mean values zero and standard deviation equal to 1.

sections.heading: 4.4 Comparative Analysis
sections.text: The K-Means, CCIA with K-Means and AGMFI are applied to serum data when the number of clusters is applied as 10 and 7 times to EIAGMFI cluster data in Fig. 6. Performance comparison diagram for serum data -0.6 -0.4 -0.2 0 0.4 0.6 0.8 50 150 250 350 450 Si lh o e tt e s Genes Serum Data K CCIAKME AGMFI CCIAGMFIFig. 3. Performance comparison diagram for yeast data -0.6-0.4-0.6 0.8 50 150 350 450 Si lh o e tt e v al e e s Genes Serum Data K CCIAKME AGMFI CCIAGMFIFig. 3. Performance comparison diagram for yeast data -0.6-0.4-0.6 0.8 0.8 50 350 450 Si lh o e t e t e t e t e t e t e t e t e s Genes Serum Data K CCIAGMFI CCIAGMFI.

sections.heading: 5 CONCLUSION
sections.text: The Evaluation of Improved Automatic Generation of Merge Factor for Clustering Microarray Data based on KMeans and AGMFI clustering algorithms were also investigated. One of the disadvantages of AGMFI is the random selection of the initial starting point of the desired clusters, which was overcome with CCIA to find the initial centroid algorithms to avoid random initial values. Therefore, the EIAGMFI algorithm is not dependent on the choice of the number of clusters and the automatic evaluation of the initial seed of the centroids. Both algorithms were tested with gene expression data.

metadata.abstractText: Microarray technology is a process that allows thousands of genes simultaneously monitor to various experimental conditions. It is used to identify the co-expressed genes in specific cells or tissues that are actively used to make proteins, This method is used to analysis the gene expression, an important task in bioinformatics research. Cluster analysis of gene expression data has proved to be a useful tool for identifying co-expressed genes, biologically relevant groupings of genes and samples. In this paper we analysed K-Means with Automatic Generations of Merge Factor for ISODATAAGMFI, to group the microarray data sets on the basic of ISODATA. AGMFI is to generate initial values for merge and Spilt factor, maximum merge times instead of selecting efficient values as in ISODATA. The initial seeds for each cluster were normally chosen either sequentially or randomly. The quality of the final clusters was found to be influenced by these initial seeds. For the real life problems, the suitable number of clusters cannot be predicted. To overcome the above drawback the current research focused on developing the clustering algorithms without giving the initial number of clusters.
